questions.question:
Question 1: If you were to conduct a death audit on all the cases of under-five paediatric deaths secondary 
to infective diarrhoea, which of the following pathogens would be responsible for the largest 
fraction of deaths?
questions.explanation:
Rotavirus is the most common identifiable viral cause of gastroenteritis in children. It accounts 
for 29% of deaths caused by diarrhoea in children aged < 5 years. 376 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: A child from an urban slum area is admitted to your unit with diarrhea. Given below are five 
important micronutrients. The deficiency of which of the following factors increases the risk 
of death due to diarrhea in this child?
questions.explanation:
The risk of death from diarrhoea is increased in the presence of deficiencies of micronutrients 
such as vitamin A, and zinc (2 and 4 only). Both these micronutrients are essential for maintaining mucosal immunity. Vitamin A deficiency 
increases mortality from diarrhoea, measles, and malaria while Zinc deficiency increases mortality 
from diarrhoea, pneumonia, and malaria. Recent studies also indicate the usefulness of folic acid in the prevention of diarrhoea.

questions.question:
Question 3: The Nutritionist in your hospital prepares the diet charts for all the children admitted with 
diarrhoeal disease. One of the advice papers has fallen off from the case file. The advice sheet 
mentions that the child has to be put on fasting some times of the day. You would attach the 
sheet back to the case file with the diagnosis of
questions.explanation:
Osmotic diarrhoea results from the presence of osmotically active, poorly absorbed solutes in the 
bowel lumen that inhibit normal water and electrolyte absorption. This type of diarrhoea ceases 
with fasting. Secretory diarrhoea, infective diarrhoea, dysentery and motility diarrhoea occurs independent of 
dietary intake and do not subside with fasting.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 5-year-old child with chronic malnutrition presents with diarrheal episodes lasting for more 
than 2 weeks. The stool sample is positive for Aeromonas and entero-adherent Escherichia 
coli. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Persistent diarrhoea(Chronic diarrhoea) is defined as a diarrhoeal episode that lasts for more than 
14 days. Diarrhoea is defined as • stool volume of more than 10 g/kg/day in toddlers/infants (or) • stool volume greater than 200 g/day in older children Persistent diarrhoea is increasingly observed in children with malnutrition. These are due to 
infections commonly caused due to enteroadherent Escherichia coli and Aeromonas. Acute diarrhoeas generally last less than 7 days while chronic diarrhoea lasts more than 14 
days and is usually a non-infectious pathology.

questions.question:
Question 5: A young child had milk-based dessert at his friend's birthday party. Later, the same evening 
he developed complaints of bloating, abdominal discomfort, and flatulence. His medical 
history is significant for viral gastroenteritis a couple of weeks back. Stool examination 
reveals an acidic pH and is positive for reducing substances. Which type of diarrhea is most 
likely to be seen in this child?
questions.explanation:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of acquired lactose intolerance which is an example of osmotic 
diarrhoea. Lactose is present in milk and dairy products. If it is not absorbed in the small intestine, it reaches 
the colon, where it is fermented to short-chain organic acids. This releases hydrogen that can be 
detected in the lactose breath test and also generates an osmotic overload. 377 
Sold by @itachibot The child with lactose intolerance generally has perianal excoriations. The condition is diagnosed 
by using stool examination which shows acidic stool positive for reducing substances. Treatment 
is by diet control using a diet devoid of lactose. It can be congenital due to lactase deficiency or 
acquired after post-viral gastroenteritis. In secretory diarrhoea, the epithelial cells’ ion transport 
processes are turned into a state of active secretion. The most common cause of acute-onset 
secretory diarrhoea is a bacterial infection of the gut. Chronic diarrhoea is, in many cases, the result of an intestinal infection that persists longer than 
expected. Dysentery/Shigellosis is a type of food poisoning caused by infection with the Shigella species. It is 
spread by means of faeco-oral transmission.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 4-year-old child was brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. No history of 
fever or blood in stools. The mother says he is irritable and eagerly drinks water if given. On 
examination, eyes are sunken and in the skin pinch test, the skin retracted within two 
seconds but not immediately. What treatment is advised for the child?

options.a: Give oral fluids and zinc supplementation only and ask mother to come back if danger sign
options.b: Give oral fluids and ask mother to continue the same and visit again the next day.
options.c: Consider severe dehydration start IV fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to higher centre.

questions.explanation:
In a child with diarrhea, thirst (eagerly drinks water), sunken eyes, restless and irritable behavior, 
and skin pinch showing slow retraction (<2 seconds) point towards some dehydration. 
Treatment includes oral rehydration therapy, zinc supplementation, and continued breastfeeding 
according to WHO integrated management of neonatal and childhood diseases (IMNCI) plan B. The degree of dehydration is assessed and managed using the WHO IMNCI PLAN given below: 378 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: 372 
Sold by @itachibot Ramya, a 6-year-old child with acute diarrhoea is admitted and started on fluid therapy with 
reduced osmolarity Oral Rehydration Solution . Which of the following statement is false 
about reduced osmolarity ORS?
questions.explanation:
The total osmolarity of reduced osmolarity ORS is 245 mOsm/L (not 311 mOsm/L) Reduced osmolarity ORS is now the global standard of care in the management of acute 
gastroenteritis.

questions.question:
Question 8: Sathish, your gym partner and father of a 12-month-old child, calls you for a teleconsult. His 
child has been passing loose watery stools without fever. He wants to know the medications 
to be given to his child. What dose of oral zinc would you prescribe to this child?
questions.explanation:
All children older than 6 months of age with acute diarrhoea should receive oral zinc (20 mg/day) 
for 10-14 days during and after diarrhoea. Most of the cases of under-five acute diarrhoea are infectious in aetiology with more than 50% 
due to the Rotavirus, which is self-limiting. Treatment will include fluid and electrolyte correction 
and zinc supplementation.

questions.question:
Question 9: In a child admitted with viral enteritis along with signs of dehydration, which type of 
acid-base imbalance is likely to be seen?
questions.explanation:
Isotonic dehydration with acidosis is the most common finding in children with severe viral 
enteritis. Viruses that cause human diarrhoea selectively infect and destroy the villus tip cells in the small 
intestine. In the small intestine, the upper villus enterocytes are differentiated cells, which have absorptive 
functions, such as the transport of water and electrolytes. On the other hand, the crypt 
enterocytes are undifferentiated cells and are net secretors of water and electrolytes. 379 
Sold by @itachibot Selective viral infection of intestinal villus tip cells thus leads to decreased absorption of salt and 
water (proportionate loss of water and salt—isotonic dehydration) and an imbalance in the ratio 
of intestinal fluid absorption to secretion. Metabolic acidosis may be a result of stool bicarbonate losses in children with diarrhoea. These 
can also be seen due to secondary renal insufficiency or lactic acidosis as a sequelae to diarrhoea.

questions.question:
Question 10: The intestinal biopsy report of a 7-year-old boy evaluated for chronic watery diarrhoea 
revealed a flat intestinal mucosa. Which of the following conditions would you suspect in this 
child?
questions.explanation:
Chronic diarrhoea with a flat intestinal mucosa can be seen in conditions Tropical sprue, 
giardiasis, and HIV enteropathy. Causes of the flat intestinal mucosa (subtotal or total villous atrophy): • Celiac disease • Tropical sprue • Giardiasis • Bacterial overgrowth • HIV enteropathy • Eosinophilic gastroenteritis • Cow’s milk or soy protein enteropathy • Graft versus host disease • Chemo or radiotherapy • Protein-energy malnutrition • Tuberculosis or lymphoma Amoebiasis and neutrophilic gastroenteritis may also rarely have villous atrophy but the 
presentation is generally acute. Amoebiasis is characteristically associated with dysentery and 
biopsy would reveal a flask-shaped ulcer.

questions.question:
Question 11: Suyash, a 10-year-old boy presented to the clinic with a history of malabsorption, diarrhoea, 
and poor appetite after having his favourite white sauce pasta. His mother adds that he 
develops such symptoms only when he takes pasta or roti. The duodenal biopsy revealed 
crypt hyperplasia and CD8+ cells in lamina propria. Which of the following tests is least likely 
to be used for the diagnosis of the condition?
questions.explanation:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of celiac disease and an anti-nuclear antibody test is not used in 
the diagnosis of celiac disease. Symptoms are pre-dominantly seen after consuming a diet rich in gluten (Wheat pasta or roti). 
Diagnosis of celiac disease is made based on lab and histopathological findings. Celiac disease-specific antibodies are as follows: • Anti-tissue transglutaminase (Anti-TG2) IgA antibodies • Anti deaminated - IgG forms of gliadin peptides antibodies • Endomysial antibodies (EMA) 380 
Sold by @itachibot The duodenal biopsy will show crypt hyperplasia, villous atrophy and CD8+ cells in lamina 
propria

questions.question:
Question 12: A 9-year-old boy presented with vomiting for 5 days. His sister, who has coeliac disease had 
similar symptoms. IgA-tissue transglutaminase titre is 5 times the upper limit of normal. 
Which of the following is not an extraintestinal manifestation of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The boy is suffering from coeliac disease. Polycythemia is not an extraintestinal manifestation of 
coeliac disease. On the contrary, the most common extraintestinal manifestation of celiac disease in the paediatric 
age group is iron-deficiency anaemia that is refractory to iron therapy, and not polycythemia. Celiac disease is an immune-mediated systemic disorder triggered by the ingestion of wheat 
gluten and related prolamines from rye and barley. The intestinal symptoms are caused by the atrophy of the small bowel mucosa and 
malabsorption. The symptoms include diarrhoea, vomiting, anorexia, weight loss, failure to 
thrive, rectal prolapse, and intussusception. The extraintestinal manifestations are caused due to malnutrition and autoimmunity and they

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is the most common cause of pancreatic insufficiency in childhood?
questions.explanation:
Cystic fibrosis is the most common cause of pancreatic insufficiency in children, which, if 
untreated, will lead to malnutrition. Other rare causes include: • Shwachman–Diamond syndrome 381 
Sold by @itachibot • Isolated enzyme deficiencies • Chronic pancreatitis • Protein-energy malnutrition

questions.question:
Question 14: 374 
Sold by @itachibot A 12-year-old boy presented to the emergency department with fever, severe epigastric pain, 
nausea and vomiting for 6 hours. He feels comfortable when he bends forward and assumes a 
knee-chest position. Which of the following tests is not useful in the diagnosis of acute 
pancreatitis?
questions.explanation:
Serum elastase is not used for the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis. The measurement of faecal 
elastase is used as a screening test for pancreatic insufficiency. The criteria for the diagnosis of pancreatitis in children is defined as 2 of 3 of the following: • Epigastric abdominal pain; • Serum amylase and/or lipase activity at least 3 times greater than the upper limit of normal; and • Imaging findings characteristic of, or compatible with, acute pancreatitis. Serum lipase is now considered the test of choice for acute pancreatitis as it is more specific than 
amylase. CT scan has a major role in the diagnosis and follow-up of children with pancreatitis. Other useful 
investigations are USG, ERCP, and MRCP.

questions.question:
Question 15: Anwesha, an orator preparing for her international debate finale presents to your clinic with 
lesions on her lower lip as shown below. She is concerned as these lesions are painful, 
recurrent and hamper the flow of her speech. Which of the following points about this 
condition is incorrect?

options.d: They are seen in Gluten-sensitive enteropathy

questions.explanation:
The lesions given in the above image are aphthous ulcers, and they are not contagious. All the 
other points are true. Aphthous ulcers are painful, recurrent, and non-contagious oral lesions. They are 
well-circumscribed, ulcerative lesions with a white necrotic base surrounded by a red halo. They 
heal in 10–14 days without scarring. Their aetiology is unclear but the following factors have been 
implicated: • Allergic or immunologic reactions • Emotional stress • Genetics • Injury to soft tissues in the mouth • Inflammatory bowel disease • Gluten-sensitive enteropathy • Behcet disease • Sweet syndrome • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection • Cyclical neutropenia 382 
Sold by @itachibot Treatment generally includes local anaesthetic to relieve pain and B-complex supplementation to 
enhance healing.

questions.question:
Question 16: 375 
Sold by @itachibot The nanny of a 3-year-old boy brings the child to the ER after he had accidentally ingested 
button batteries from the mobile phone toy that he was playing with. What would be the next 
best step in the management of this child?
questions.explanation:
Button batteries and sharp objects in the oesophagus and foreign bodies associated with 
respiratory symptoms all mandate urgent endoscopic removal. Button batteries, in particular, are very dangerous foreign bodies, which must be expediently 
removed because they can cause: • Mucosal injury in 1-hour contact time • Involve all layers of the oesophagus in 4 hours Injury is thought to be secondary to electrochemical burns from electrical discharge. Chemical 
burns from electrolyte alkali leakage and pressure necrosis also may contribute to mucosal injury. Asymptomatic blunt objects and coins lodged in the oesophagus can be observed for up to 24 hr 
in anticipation of passage into the stomach. 383 
Sold by @itachibot Disorders of the Liver
